content.text: Using the ruler in Fig. 1.1, determine the distance AB on Fig. 1.1
distance AB = .........\(cm\)
Use the distance AB to determine the diameter of one steel ball
diameter of one steel ball = .........\(cm\)
The mass of some steel balls is \(54\mathrm{g}\) and the total volume of these steel balls is \(6.9\mathrm{cm}^3\)
Calculate the density of the steel
density of steel = .........\(g / cm^3\)
A student measures the diameter of some identical steel balls. Fig. 1.1 shows the arrangement she uses
constant speed
constant deceleration
constant non-zero acceleration
In Fig. 2.1, the sections ST, TW, WX, XY and YZ indicate stages of the cyclist's journey
State **one** section which shows the cyclist **moving** with:
Calculate the distance travelled by the cyclist in section ST
distance travelled = .........m
Calculate the size of the resultant force on the cyclist
resultant force = .........N
State the effect, if any, of the resultant force on the motion of the cyclist
Fig. 2.2 shows the horizontal forces on a cyclist
Fig. 2.1 shows the speed–time graph for a cyclist
Fig. 3.2 shows the energy transfers when the torch is switched on. The diagram is incomplete
Show the energy transfers in the torch by completing the labels on Fig. 3.2
The weight of the torch is \(8.5 \text{N}\). The student lifts the torch a vertical distance of \(0.80 \text{m}\) to place it on a shelf
Calculate the work done on the torch by the student
work done = .........J
The student places the torch on its base on a shelf. The area of the base of the torch is \(44 \text{cm}^2\). The weight of the torch is \(8.5 \text{N}\)
Calculate the pressure on the shelf due to the torch
pressure on shelf = .........N/cm²
A student has a battery-powered torch. Fig. 3.1 shows the torch
Describe the arrangement, separation and motion of the particles in the solid metal
The student cools the block of metal in a freezer
State the effect, if any, of cooling on the kinetic energy of the particles in the block of metal
State the name of the temperature at which particles have the least kinetic energy
State the value of temperature at which particles have the least kinetic energy. Include the unit
The metal block emits thermal radiation from its surface
State two features of a surface that is a good emitter of thermal radiation
A student has a block of solid metal at room temperature
Calculate the distance XP from the explosion at X to the observer at P
distance XP = .........m
The observer then hears a quieter sound from the explosion
Suggest how the quieter sound waves reach the observer
The observer first hears the sound from the explosion 1.8 s after the explosion occurs. The speed of the sound is \(340 \text{m/s}\)
Before the explosion, a warning siren produces a sound. The wavelength of the sound is \(0.28 \text{m}\)
The speed of the sound is \(340 \text{m/s}\)
Calculate the frequency of the sound
frequency = .........Hz
An observer stands at P and looks into a rock quarry. A small explosion takes place at X in the quarry
Fig. 5.1 shows the situation
State the name of the process shown in Fig. 6.1 as the wavefronts enter the glass block
State two changes in the light waves as they pass from air into glass
Fig. 6.2 shows a ray of red light travelling through a glass fibre. The glass fibre is made of solid glass
State and explain how the ray of red light travels through the glass fibre as shown in Fig. 6.2
Fig. 6.1 shows light waves passing from air into a glass block
Each nail lifts the nail below it by induced magnetism
Describe what is meant by induced magnetism
The student leaves the nails attached to the magnet for several hours, then removes the magnet
State a difference between a magnetic property of the iron nails and of the steel nails
State the reading on the voltmeter when the wire is stationary between the poles
Give a reason for the reading on the voltmeter when the wire is moving in the direction shown in Fig. 7.2
A metal wire XY is connected to a voltmeter. The wire is placed between the poles of a permanent magnet. Fig. 7.2 shows the arrangement
A student uses a permanent magnet to lift some unmagnetised nails. Some of the nails are made of iron and some are made of steel. Fig. 7.1 shows the magnet lifting the nails
The symbols for the meters in Fig. 8.1 are incomplete
Complete the symbols for the two meters by writing in the circles in Fig. 8.1
The current in the heater is 1.4A and the potential difference (p.d.) across the heater is 8.0V
Calculate the resistance of the heater
resistance = .........\(\Omega\)
The heater is switched on for 30s. The current in the heater is 1.4A and the p.d. across it is 8.0V
Calculate the electrical energy transferred by the heater during the 30s
energy transferred = .........J
A student uses the circuit in Fig. 8.1 to measure the resistance of the heater in the circuit
The desktop computer has an on-off switch in one of the wires that connect it to the mains supply
State and explain which wire includes the switch
State the name of this type of transformer
Describe the construction of this transformer. You may include a labelled diagram
The desktop computer uses a transformer to change the \(240\mathrm{V}\) a.c. voltage to a \(12\mathrm{V}\) a.c. voltage
A student has a desktop computer that connects to the \(240\mathrm{V}\) a.c. mains electrical supply. Fig. 9.1 shows the desktop computer
Determine the number of protons in one nucleus of iodine-131
number of protons = .........
Determine the number of neutrons in one nucleus of iodine-131
number of neutrons = .........
When a nucleus of iodine-131 decays, it emits a beta \((\beta)\) -particle and a gamma \((\gamma)\) ray
State the nature of a beta-particle and a gamma ray
A beta-particle is
A gamma ray is
A sample contains \(1.6 \text{mg}\) of iodine-131
The half-life of iodine-131 is 8.0 days
Calculate the mass of iodine-131 remaining in the sample after 24.0 days
mass of iodine-131 remaining = .........mg
Iodine-131 is a radioactive isotope of the element iodine. Fig. 10.1 shows the nuclide notation for a nucleus of iodine-131
In Table 11.1, write the names of the innermost planets. One is done for you
Describe how the four innermost planets of the Solar System were formed
Fig. 11.1 shows the Sun and the four innermost planets, A, B, C, and D, of the Solar System
